author: potuz
content:
<@!425572898787426305> , regarding https://hackmd.io/GDc0maGsQeKfP8o2C7L52w, I agree with the specification as in that document, but I find that you can't really distinguish the synchronous vs asynchronous implementation (in the sense that any EC can claim to be syncing at any time). So given this, I do not really see any point in complicating the implementation. I tend to agree with Adrian that if LVH is not useful as in the current spec, then it may as well not be there that that would be fine. So I think that a very simple specification like 
```
If validation fails, the response MUST contain {status: INVALID, latestValidHash: validHash} where validHash is either empty or the block hash of the most recent valid ancestor of the invalid payload. That is, the valid ancestor of the payload with the highest blockNumber
```
Which is simply 4 words different than the current specification and leaves the EL to do whatever it wants.

author: potuz
content: In particular, returning the parent hash is seldomly useful: if no lvh is returned, then we will assume this is the case. While if you return the parent hash we will have to 1) check that the hash is there in forkchoice and it's known, 2) check that it's an ancestor of the invalid block, etc...

author: paulhauner
content:
Thereâ€™s two factors involved with getting slashed (slashing here means producing conflicting messages), assuming that clients implement slashing protection correctly (I have no reason to believe they donâ€™t):

1. Running the same validator keys in two different validator clients.
2. Having those two different validator clients produce conflicting information. Itâ€™s not uncommon for users to run duplicate setups for some time before that setup actually causes them to be slashed. 

I have no reason to believe the client implementations of slashing protection will be affected by the merge, I expect the slashing protection system to be well insulated from practically all changes introduced by the merge. 

For (1), users upgrading their setups to support the new merge configuration might result in them making mistakes and running the same keys twice. For example, starting a new, more powerful machine to run EL+CL and forgetting to turn the old one off. 

For (2), the merge might introduce some turbulence into the network which might cause already misconfigured setups to produce conflicting messages, simply because some nodes will have slightly different views of the networks.

So, I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if we saw some more slashings during the merge. However, I donâ€™t expect users who are running safe (non-duplicate) setups to get slashed from no fault of their own.

So, I donâ€™t think that turning your system off for 24hrs will help. If you have a duplicate setup youâ€™ll almost certainly get slashed at some point. I also wouldnâ€™t recommend people turn off their setups during the merge, since if enough people do that then we wonâ€™t have enough validators to finalise the chain!
